Last fall the Austrians, Germans, and Bulgarians
overran and conquered Serbia, and now that

5.text:
the dust had settled from that campaign, the
Balkans were kicking into high gear again,

11.text: as this week, Austria-Hungary invades Montenegro.

19.text: I’m Indy Neidell; welcome to the Great War.

21.text:
Last week the Russians attacked up and down
the eastern front, but didn’t do much except

26.text:
produce corpses. There was scattered action
in the west, but the Italian and Balkan fronts

30.text:
were quiet, and a British relief force heading
up the Tigris River lost a third of its men

37.text:
There was new fighting on the Western Front
this week, as the Germans went on the attack.

42.text:
This week they recovered the trenches they
had lost to the French at Hartmannsweilerkopf

46.text:
New Year’s Eve and captured 20 officers,
and on the 9th German troops under General

50.text:
von Einem attacked on a five-mile front east
of Tahure after an artillery barrage. The

56.text:
French managed to stop the offensive, but
at two points the Germans reached the French

61.text:
front lines. This was actually a three-day
battle, and the Germans took several hundred

65.text:
meters of trenches, 423 prisoners and, 8 machine
guns.

70.text:
At Massiges, after an artillery barrage of
400,000 shells, the Germans charged 40,000

77.text:
strong on the 10th, but the French machine
guns tore huge holes in the attackers and

81.text:
they were forced back. Few even made it as
far as the barbed wire. This sounds pretty

86.text:
serious, but by the 13th, all of this German
activity had pretty much been called off.

91.text:
Something that was called off weeks ago, but
was still not entirely finished, was Gallipoli.

97.text:
But this week, on January 8th, the total evacuation
of the British forces at Gallipoli was complete.

104.text:
Anzac and Suvla Bay had been evacuated in
December, but there were still tens of thousands

109.text:
of men at Cape Helles and it was a difficult
situation. The route to the beach had to be

114.text:
marked off carefully and then all other avenues
of advance for the Turks blocked with barbed

120.text:
wire. This had to be done under the ever-increasing
Turkish artillery, and the ever-increasing

126.text:
suspicions by the Turks as to what was going
on. The Turks even went over the top on January

132.text:
7th, but were pushed back by British naval
support hammering their flanks. At that time

137.text:
there were only 19,000 men left and only 63
guns at Cape Helles. If the Turks had broken

144.text: through it could have been a true massacre.

147.text:
In the last 11 days, 35,628 troops were removed.
They left behind them booby traps, land mines,

156.text:
and even rifles that operated by clockwork;
water would drip through a tin of sand and

162.text:
when that tin dropped it would set off the
trigger and fire the gun. The relief of the

167.text:
men was palpable, and one Sergeant Mannion,
one of the last to leave, had this to say,

174.text:
“When we were a mile out from the beach,
we were all ordered to go below. At this moment

179.text:
a big magazine on shore was blown up, and
we could hear the pieces of scrap-iron falling

185.text:
on the roof of the lighter. The sea was very
rough and our lighter pitched and tossed like

189.text:
a cork on the waves. We were all very seasick.
There was a rumor that we had broken adrift,

195.text:
and the sailors confirmed this. Our cable
had parted and we were drifting, in a rough

201.text:
sea, off a hostile shore. But nobody seemed
to worry much. We had got safely off Gallipoli,

207.text:
a thing which none of us had expected.”
(Gilbert)

210.text:
The evacuation was carried off brilliantly,
there’s no doubt about that, but while it

214.text:
was a great success, it was a success that
grew out of defeat and there were many cynics

220.text:
about it. Peter Hart quotes Douglas Jerrold,
in The Great War, with having this to say:

225.text:
“The evacuation, the world has repeatedly
been informed, was a very skillful operation.

231.text:
The phrase is just stupid. It does not require
intelligence... to withdraw troops quietly

237.text:
by night instead of noisily by day, or to
withdraw them gradually instead of all at

242.text:
once. Or to hold the front line to the last
and so conceal your intentions from the enemy.

249.text:
There were no casualties because the Turks
did not attack... If the Turks had chanced

253.text:
to launch a powerful attack on the last day
no staff work could have prevented the loss

260.text:
of most of the few troops left behind there.
But the risk... was negligible. It was, as

266.text:
everyone has said, a miracle of organization.
We are good at that sort of thing. When we

271.text:
surrender the last defenses of our Empire,
we may be certain that the protocols, like

277.text: the graves, will be in perfect order.”

281.text:
In addition to the men, there were 3,689 horses
and mules to be transported, though 508 were

289.text:
shot, and 1,590 vehicles abandoned (numbers
from Gilbert). For the Allies, the campaign

294.text:
was a huge drain on manpower that could’ve,
should’ve been used elsewhere. 410,000 men

302.text:
from the British Empire participated, with
79,000 more from France and its North African

307.text:
colonies. The British Imperial forces lost
205,000 men, half their total; 115,000 killed,

315.text:
wounded, or missing, and 90,000 evacuated
sick (Hart). Really, that’s how bad the

321.text:
disease was there. French losses were proportionally
higher- 47,000; 27.000 killed, wounded, or

332.text:
The evacuation of Gallipoli also meant that
the Turks could now transfer nearly 40,000

337.text:
troops to Mesopotamia, where the British were
under siege at Kut Al-Amara.

341.text:
But the relief force under Fenton Aylmer was
on the move up the Tigris River, even after

347.text:
having a third of its men killed or wounded
last week. They saw more action this week,

351.text:
although on a smaller scale, at the Battle
of the Wadi on the 13th. 200 British and Indian

357.text:
troops were killed and another 1,400 wounded.
While I guess you could technically call it

362.text:
a victory for the British, since they did
succeed in taking the Wadi River area, they

367.text:
took three times the casualties of the Ottoman
defenders, and theirs were not replaceable

373.text:
so by most measures it was a win for the Ottomans
over the invading forces.

379.text:
Meanwhile back in Europe, a brand new invasion
was taking place.

383.text:
After the events of the previous months, a
period of calm had seemed to settle over the

388.text:
Balkans, with one real exception- Montenegro.
Although you didn’t hear much about it,

393.text:
the Montenegrin army had fought against the
Austrians. It now numbered fewer than 20,000

399.text:
men and was desperately short of munitions
and food, but the allies couldn’t really

403.text:
offer them any relief. There was no real seaport
and the terrain was mountainous and difficult.

409.text:
Now, during the invasion of Serbia in the
fall, Montenegrin forces had given Serbia

414.text:
their full support and had faced the Austrians,
even holding a slice of Bosnia for a little

420.text:
while. The Austrians had been content then
to just hold back the Montenegrins, since

425.text:
an invasion into the mountainous country would
be tricky, but as Serbia fell, the Austrians

430.text:
were strongly reinforced with men and big
guns.

434.text:
Lim, and Ibar while Austrian warships bombarded
mount Lovcen. On January 8th, over 50,000

436.text:
Austro-Hungarian Imperial troops invaded Montenegro
with a 500-gun barrage, and both air and sea

443.text:
support. Mount Lovcen was stormed and taken
on the 10th and it was just a matter of time

448.text:
before Cetinje, the capital, fell. It was
occupied at the end of the week as more and

453.text: more Austrian forces surged into Montenegro.

457.text:
And it wasn’t just tiny Montenegro that
was in chaos this week. Giant Russia was also

463.text:
On the Black Sea, 10,000 Russian workers went
on strike at the naval base at Nikolaev, the

469.text:
strike would spread to Petrograd, where next
week 45,000 dock workers walked off their

475.text:
jobs. Russia was also fighting, still pretty
continuously in Bukovina and Galicia, but

481.text:
also launching an offensive in Anatolia, occupying
Arkhava on the Black Sea on the 14th.

487.text:
And that was the week, the British losing
irreplaceable men in the Middle East, the

492.text:
Germans trying in the west, strikes in Russia,
and the final exit from Gallipoli.

497.text:
There are 33 Commonwealth cemeteries at Gallipoli
on the peninsula, with graves for the bodies

504.text:
that were found with inscriptions on them
covering all spectrums of human emotion. Here

509.text: are two I got from Martin Gilbert.

511.text:
“Brother Bill a sniping fell:
We love him still,

517.text:
And one that I think sums up the thoughts
of every parent of every dead soldier from

525.text: “What harm did he do thee, O Lord?”
